content:
The America INNOVATES Act includes provisions for innovation management at the Department of Energy and promoting cross-sector partnerships and grant competitiveness. The America INNOVATES Act includes provisions for commercializing technology, public-private partnerships, early-stage technology demonstration, resources for startups and small businesses, and funding competitiveness for institutions of higher education. It also includes an assessment of impact through a report by the Government Accountability Office. Definitions in the Act include terms like Department, National Laboratory, and Secretary. SEC. 3. SAVINGS CLAUSE. This Act does not affect the primary responsibilities of any National Laboratory to the Department. TITLE I--INNOVATION MANAGEMENT AT DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY SEC. 101. UNDER SECRETARY FOR SCIENCE AND ENERGY. The Department of Energy Organization Act is amended to change the title of the Under Secretary for Science to the Under Secretary for Science and Energy. The Under Secretary is now required to establish linkages between offices and perform duties as prescribed by the Secretary. Conforming amendments are also made. The Department of Energy Organization Act is amended to change the title of the Under Secretary for Science to the Under Secretary for Science and Energy. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of different acts to reflect this change. SEC. 102. NATIONAL LABORATORIES OPERATIONS AND PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT. The Secretary is responsible for overseeing duties related to promoting the transfer of National Laboratory research to the market, submitting reports on best practices for the labs, and implementing other improvements as needed. The Secretary is responsible for overseeing the performance of National Laboratories and providing annual updates on progress made in improving operations and coordination. SENSE OF SENATE ON AN INTEGRATED STRATEGY FOR NATIONAL LABORATORIES IN THE 21ST CENTURY. The Senate acknowledges the importance of establishing an independent Commission to Review the Effectiveness of the National Energy Laboratories for developing a coordinated strategy in the 21st century. Congress anticipates receiving the Commission's findings and engaging with the Administration to strengthen the mission and modernize the operations of the National Laboratories. TITLE II--CROSS-SECTOR PARTNERSHIPS AND GRANT COMPETITIVENESS

SEC. 201. AGREEMENTS FOR COMMERCIALIZING TECHNOLOGY PILOT PROGRAM. The Secretary will implement the Agreements for Commercializing Technology pilot program, providing increased negotiation authority to National Laboratory contractors for contract terms like intellectual property rights and payment structures. Any National Laboratory can participate in the program, including agreements with non-federal entities. The Secretary will allow National Laboratory directors to enter agreements with non-Federal entities, including those already receiving Federal funding. Restrictions apply under the Bayh-Dole Act for funding agreements involving eligible parties. The National Laboratory directors can enter agreements with non-Federal entities, including those already receiving Federal funding, under the Bayh-Dole Act. Each director must submit project details, costs, and timelines to the Secretary for approval. The contractor must certify that the project does not compete with the private sector and minimizes conflicts. The pilot program under the Bayh-Dole Act allows National Laboratory directors to enter agreements with non-Federal entities, ensuring no conflict of interest. The program will be extended for 3 years, and a report assessing its effectiveness will be submitted to relevant committees. The pilot program under the Bayh-Dole Act allows National Laboratory directors to enter agreements with non-Federal entities, ensuring no conflict of interest. It will be extended for 3 years, and a report will assess the program's potential interference with National Laboratories' responsibilities and provide a recommendation for its future. SEC. 202. PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS FOR COMMERCIALIZATION. The Secretary can delegate signature authority to National Laboratory directors for agreements under $1,000,000. This applies to various types of agreements and must be carried out in accordance with Department policies. The director of a National Laboratory must ensure that agreements do not compromise national security, economic, or environmental interests. Certification is required to avoid conflicts of interest, and all records related to the agreement must be submitted for monitoring. The director of a National Laboratory can charge higher rates for services under a partnership agreement, regardless of full cost recovery. Amendments to the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 allow for exceptions to standard agency procedures. The America INNOVATES Act exempts technology transfer agreements under $1,000,000 from Secretary of Energy approval at National Laboratories. Subsection (b) references subsection (a)(1)(A) instead of (a)(1). SEC. 203 amends the Energy Policy Act of 2005 to include early-stage technology demonstration in authorized technology transfer activities. SEC. 204 provides information and resources for startups and small businesses. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to provide information on resources available to small businesses at National Laboratories and research centers. Section 988(b) of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 is amended to include an exemption for research activities by institutions of higher education and nonprofit institutions. This exemption applies for a 6-year period. The exemption for research activities by institutions of higher education and nonprofit institutions under Section 988(b) of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 applies for a 6-year period from the date of enactment. TITLE III--ASSESSMENT OF IMPACT

SEC. 301. REPORT BY GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 3 years of the Act's enactment, detailing the outcomes of projects under sections 201, 202, and 203. This report will include information on partnerships formed, fiscal savings, National Laboratory capabilities, technology transfers, and overall efficiency improvements.
